p: Incorporating both large scale (i.e. climatic) and smaller scale factors, including biological interactions, microtopography, and microclimate, is important for realistic predictions of species distributions, which is essential for practical spatial conservation planning [ 46, 52]. Previous studies that have predicted the potential habitat for L. muta japonica in Europe were conducted at the macro-scale (100 km 2) and meso-scale (1 km 2), mainly taking climatic factors into consideration [ 18, 20]. Our study is the first to incorporate the effects of environmental factors at a micro-scale (i.e. the territory scale) to predict the potential habitat of L. muta japonica.
